both of our families like to understand
at first
but um and their relationships better
than it's ever been
maya and her partner zach are both
transgender their families are now
supportive of their transition but their
journey hasn't been easy i was 16 17 18
in and out of homelessness
became like addicted to drugs and
alcohol it's kind of crazy to look at
myself now and be like oh my god i've
got my dream job i've got a flight i've
got a girlfriend i've got two cats and
i've got family the couple who are both
24 support reform of scotland's gender
recognition act to make it less
intrusive you need to have like so much
evidence it's just really invasive and
it puts you in a position
of being mentally and physically
exhausted with having to do it but zach
feels it's important to be sure
i definitely support it i think people
who are younger they need to explore
themselves they need to get to know
themselves they need to like i didn't
even know what job i wanted to do when i
was 16. some people might not even know
that let alone what gender they wanted
to sit in for the rest of their life
in a poll commissioned by the bbc more
than half of those questioned were in
favor of making it easier to get a
gender recognition certificate a fifth
opposed it but on some of the specific
proposals opinion was more finely
balanced there were almost equal levels
of support and opposition for allowing
transgender people to self-identify by
removing the requirement for a medical
diagnosis of gender dysphoria
44 percent of those questioned opposed
reducing the time someone must have
lived in their gender identity from two
years to six months 37 percent supported
it
and a slight majority opposed reducing
the legal age a person can transition
from 18 to 16 or just under a third were
in favor
the survey also suggests more support
than opposition for transgender people
to access single-sex spaces such as
changing rooms 35 said they should be
able to do so only if they'd legally
change sex and had gender reassignment
surgery 28 said this should be allowed
even if they had not had surgery
some people this is a fundamental and
polarizing issue
with protests on both sides
we believe this proposal should bring in
self-identification will mean that we
will not be able to confront any mail
that is in within our changing rooms we
might actually be breaking the law be
perceived as being transphobic by
questioning why a male was there because
they were saying they would just sign up
and say but i self-identify as a woman
i'm allowed to be in this space
but some scottish women's advocacy
groups highlight that trans women
already access services like rape and
domestic violence support we have no
concerns about the proposed reforms we
know that trans women access women's
services anyway we don't believe there
are any proposed changes to the in the
bill that will impact on single sex
spaces which already operate on a basis
of self-id the scottish government is
likely to bring this bill to parliament
in the next few weeks
some people have clear and strongly held
positions on this issue but this poll
suggests many others are undecided lorna
gordon bbc news edinburgh
